seg.seg: ... the monks are taking the jewels [for] themselves. The Buddha heard [of it] and scolded [them]. If a monk picks up a jewel with his own hand [or] orders [someone] to give [it to him], that jewel must be given up.

niḥsargika 18. The Buddha was in Rājagṛha. The Ṣaḍvargikas were engaging in trade (lit. were doing buying, price, exchange, giving). The householder's business (lit. way of possessions) was not possible. Therefore,

Der Buddha befand sich in Rājagṛha. Die Ṣaḍvārgikas nahmen Kauf, Verkauf [und] In-Tausch-Geben vor. Den Haushaltern war ein Handel mit Besitz nicht möglich. Daher waren die Haushalter übelgesinnt [und] tadelten [es]. Der Buddha hörte [und] tadelte [es]: "Welcher Mönch einen Edelstein/ein Wertobjekt für einen anderen Edelstein/Wertobjekt tauscht im Gedanken an einen Gewinn, der soll den Edelstein zurückgeben."

The Buddha was sojourning in Rājagṛha.. The Ṣaḍvārgikas conducted buying, selling [and] bartering. For the householders, trading with possessions was not possible. Therefore, the householders were evil-minded [and] scolded. The Buddha heard [this] and rebuked [it]: "Whichever monk exchanges a jewel/object of value for another jewel/object of value thinking of profit, he shall return the jewel."
the householders were upset. They scolded [them]. The Buddha heard [of it] and scolded [them]. If a monk trades a jewel for a jewel with profit in mind, that jewel must be given up.
niḥsargika 19. The Buddha was in Śrāvasti. An Ājivika came to Upananda. He was wearing red cotton. Upananda begged him for the cotton

Zu Upananda kam ein Ājīvika. Er trug einen roten Mantel [wtl. hatte einen r.M. angezogen]. Upananda erbat von ihm den Mantel; er [aber] gab ihn nicht [her]. Darauf tauschte er ihn gegen einen schlecht[er]en ein.
An Ājīvika came to Upananda. He wore a red coat [lit. had put on a red coat]. Upananda asked him for the coat; [but] he didi not give it [away]. Then he traded it for bad [i.e. worse] one.

[but] he didn't give [it] to him. Then he exchanged it for inferior [cotton]. They asked him: “Did you discard (lit. do away) the cloak?” He said: “I swapped [it] for Upananda's.” Then the householders scolded him
Sie fragten ihn: "Hast du [deinen] Mantel weggegeben [wtl. weggetan]?"
They asked him: "Have you given [lit. put] away your cloak?"
Darauf tadelten ihn die Hausgenossen [und] schalten ihn [mit den Worten]: "[Wenn] du den Mantel nicht zurückbringst, werden wir dich infolgedessen vertreiben."
Thereupon the housemates rebuked him [and] scolded him [saying]: "If you do not bring back the coat, we will drive you away because of this."
and threatened him: “If you don't bring back the cloak, we will expel you.” Then he demanded the cloak back from Upananda. Upananda didn't give [it] to him.
If you don't give away the mantle, then we will drive you away because of that.
[Wenn] du den Mantel nicht zurückbringst, werden wir dich infolgedessen vertreiben.
[If] you do not bring back the cloak, we will therefore expel you.
Darauf erbat er den Mantel von Upananda zurück.
Thereupon he requested [to get] the coat back from Upananda.

He said this to him: “You traded with me. I'm not giving [it] to you.” He went to the assembly. He told this matter to all believers and non-believers. They greatly scolded Upananda. The Buddha heard [of it] and scolded [him].
If a monk engages in trade (lit. does buying and price), buys low and sells high for the sake of profit, that must be given up by him. niḥsargika 20. The Buddha was in Rājagṛha.
Wenn ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch] Kauf [und] Verkauf vornimmt, billig(?) einkauft [und] teuer verkauft um des Gewinnes willen, [so] soll das von ihm zurückgegeben werden.
Whichever monk undertakes [to] buy [and] sell, buys cheaply(?) [and] sells dearly for the sake of profit, this shall be given back by him.
The Ṣaḍvargikas accumulated many alms bowls. They were putting them aside and weren't using them. There they were looking for it (??). The monks saw this
Die Ṣaḍvārgikas sammelten viele Almosenschalen, legten [sie] weg [beiseite] [und] machten keinen Gebrauch [davon].
The Ṣaḍvārgikas gathered many alms bowls, put [them] away [and] made no use [of them].
Die Mönche sahen das [und] tadelten [es] [d.h. wurden ungehalten und gaben dem Ausdruck]
The monks saw this [and] reproached [it] [i.e. became indignant and spoke accordingly]
and scolded [them]. The Buddha heard [of this] and scolded [them]. For ten days an alms bowl may be held on to by a monk. Then he holds on longer ...

Translation [[Ogihara 2009]]: 327-328:
a1 The monks belonging to Śākya carry off the jewels by himselves. Buddha heard and blamed. If a monk picks up the jewel by his own hand, or orders someone to give (it him), the jewel
a2 should be abandoned. NP. 18 || Buddha was staying in Rājagṛha. The monks of the group of six made trade. The way for the possession of the householder did not go aright. Because of this,
a3 the householders were irritated, and blamed them. Buddha heard and blamed. If a monk exchanges the jewel with the jewel with the thought of profit, the jewel
a4 should be abandoned. NP. 19 || Buddha stayed in Śrāvastī. An Ājīvika came to Upananda. He was dressed in a red cloak. Upananda begged the cloak from him.
a5 He did not give him. Then, he (=Upananda) exchanged it with a bad one. They (=the other Ājīvikas) asked him. 'Did you set the cloak aside?' He said, 'I exchanged (it) with Upananda.' Then, the householders blamed him and
b1 threatened him. 'If you do not give back the cloak, because of this, we will banish you away in this way.' Then, he begged the cloak from Upananda. Upananda did not give it back.
b2 He (=Upananda) said to him. 'You exchanged with me. I will not give (it) back to you.' He went to the assembly, and told this story to the believers and the unbelievers, to all of them. They blamed Upananda. Buddha heard and blamed.
b3 If a monk makes trade, and buys cheap and sells dear for profit, it should be abandoned by him. NP.20 || Buddha was staying in Rājagṛha.
b4 The monks of the group of six gathered many alms-bowls. They left them aside and did not use them. Then, there were [the seekers of it]. The monks looked at this,
b5 and blamed. Buddha heard and blamed. The alms-bowl [should be seized] by a monk at most during ten days. If he seized it more than that, this alms-bowl (should be abandoned.)
